awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Enhancing Proprioception via Model-Based Human-Robot Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Proprioception is the sense of body position and movement that comes from specialized sensors in the joints and muscles of the body. Proprioception is impaired on one side of the body in about half of stroke survivors. The research objective of this project is to develop personalized robotic interventions targeting upper extremity rehabilitation for people with proprioceptive impairments after neurological injury such as stroke. The project will conduct human subject experiments, develop novel computational models, and use machine learning methods to enhance the design of personalized, subject-adaptive robotic interventions that are optimized for each individual's specific profile of impairment. This project will promote the progress of science and advance national health by developing new robotic therapies that have the potential to improve quality of life for a large number of people with sensorimotor impairments after stroke. Additionally, the work may increase national prosperity by reducing the healthcare cost burden of stroke through optimization of neurorehabilitative techniques and their robotic delivery. Broader impacts of the project include efforts to expose a diverse group of high school students to biomechanics through activities associated with National Biomechanics Day and a workshop to be developed.

This project will examine how humans combine visual and proprioceptive information to estimate upper limb position, and then use these data to guide the development and testing of robot-aided rehabilitation in stroke survivors. The project will conduct three sets of activities: 1) human subject experiments exploiting human-robotic interactions to characterize stroke-related deficits of multisensory integration during the assessment of limb posture and movement; 2) the development of novel extensions to Bayesian models of multi-sensory integration and evaluation of their ability to describe impaired multisensory cue combination post-stroke; and 3) the design and implementation of individualized, robot-assisted, subject-adaptive training algorithms to rehabilitate multisensory function in upper limb impairment after stroke. This project advances the M3X program vision because it exploits human-robot interactions not only to interrogate the sensorimotor state of individuals after stroke, but to also drive improvement in sensorimotor function using an individualized robotic training approach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project broadly aimed to understand how disruptions (e.g., from brain injury due to stroke) to different forms of sensory information impacts a person’s ability to interact with their world. The project focused on two main forms of sensory information that are tightly linked to motor control, visual information and proprioceptive information - which is our sensation of body position and movement. This project aimed to use robotics and eye-tracking techniques to improve our understanding of how proprioception and other sensory impairments impact arm sensation and movement after stroke, as there are no “gold standard” methods for the effective rehabilitation of sensory impairments.  

This project developed novel robotic tools to improve approaches to address how proprioceptive impairments of the upper limb affect multi-sensory integration after stroke.  Here, we developed several new robotic assessments, models, and a training method. We found that magnitude and amount of proprioceptive error is impacted by both age and neurologic condition (stroke), where both older adults and stroke survivors exhibit patterns of proprioceptive errors that are different from younger adults, suggesting alterations in the patterning of sensory errors evolve with age and are negatively impacted by neural injury.

This project also implemented novel multi-method approaches to examine multi-sensory integration that occurs between the limb and eyes to execute arm movements. Here, we utilized robotics and gaze-tracking techniques and found that proprioceptive impairments of the limb can significantly affect the transmission of sensory information and resultant motor execution of eye movements. This finding demonstrates that impairments in proprioceptive processing of the limb affects critical information for hand-eye coordination after stroke. These findings are some of the first to show that multi-sensory processing in stroke is disrupted and does not just affect limb-based motor systems, but the generation of eye movements as well. As this relationship has not been examined before, these findings provide critical information for the guidance of sensory-based personalized robotic rehabilitation and additionally suggest the need for multi-modal assessments to comprehensively capture sensorimotor impairments after stroke. 

This project also developed several novel methods that aimed to “close the loop” between upper limb robotic assessment and robotic training for the purpose of tailoring these methods to the impairment level of individual patient participants. By incorporating robotic task design that integrates level and state of participant impairment level, we are able to more precisely identify sensory impairments and decrease time spent on measurement. Two novel assessment methods were developed to optimized task design for individual participants. The first approach explored three methods to optimize length and type of delivery of stimulus to the participants. This approach personalizes the assessment and reduces testing time required, where short testing times are ideal for testing patient participants and ease of use in clinical environments.  The second was a novel approach for detecting proprioceptive speed thresholds in stroke survivors. This technique measured limb motion detection thresholds that integrated participant performance on a trial-by-trial basis and newly considered overall level of impairment as a factor in the design of the measurement. Here, we found that impairments in speed detection thresholds are a promising indicator of both sensory and motor impairments of the upper limb after stroke. 

This project also designed and implemented a novel robotic training methodology that directly targeted proprioceptive impairment of the arm by including real-time proprioceptive feedback, minimizing visual information, and promoting active participation of both arms by the participant. Here, stroke participants used real-time proprioceptive information for passive guidance of the more-affected arm. We found that within a one-day training session, stroke participants improved motor function and some aspects of proprioceptive function, suggesting that this technique is a promising approach for implementing into a longer-term study or clinical trial that focuses on determining the long-term efficacy of proprioceptive training on sensorimotor outcomes.

Findings from this project have laid critical groundwork for improvement of the techniques by which we measure and treat sensory impairments in individuals with stroke.  Through this, these techniques will allow for more precise identification of the different types of sensory impairments that patients may experience through tailored, patient-driven assessment. Additionally, these techniques can be easily translated into use for other neurologic conditions with known sensory impairment issues (e.g., Parkinson’s disease, Multiple Sclerosis). The training techniques developed and tested within this project lay important foundational work to design and implement efficacious robotic sensory training protocols for future studies and clinical trial work.

 


Last Modified: 03/17/2025
Modified by: Jennifer Semrau
